render.tex: %text \textcolor{blue}{\text{Polynomial Factorization} Expressing a polynomial as the \underline\text{product or quotient} of other polynomials %

reason.tex:
%text If you write \[ x = 2 = \frac{4}{2} \], then you are not changing the value of $x$ - only how it is written.
Same goes for polynomials.
Sometimes, the math becomes easier if one simply re-writes the given polynomials as the product or quotient of some other polynomials.
Knowing the \underline\text{following expansions} should cover you in most cases
% \begin{align} (x-a)^2 & = x^2 - 2ax + a^2 \\ (x+a)^2 &= x^2 + 2ax + a^2 \\ (x^2-a^2) &= (x-a)\cdot (x+a) \\ (x-a)^3 &= x^3 - 3ax^2 + 3a^2 x - a^3 \\ (x+a)^3 &= x^3 + 3ax^2 + 3a^2 x + a^3 \\ x^3 - a^3 &= (x-a)\cdot (x^2 + ax + a^2) \\ x^3 + a^3 &= (x+a)\cdot (x^2 - ax + a^2) \end{align}
